Message.Title: Rewarding Mediocrity
Message.Msg: Leads to misallocation of assets and resources. AMZN is poster child for this phenomenon. Wasted investment in digital content, devices and other services. The so called investment phase that started years ago hasn't and won't pay dividends - gross margin games are keeping the dream alive but like in all cases the wheel of reality grinds slow but will grind fine one day. when profits never show up and growth slows to a crawl (see 1Q13 projections for proof) the value of the company must be alligned to reality. growth has declined some 60% and although 18% yoy is great for most retail - the writing on the wall is ever more ominous given the context of the 122B market cap. they really don't have an answer to this problem and with more and more facilities and employess and new investment strategies, the wall gets higher and higher. there is not an easy exit strategy here and they don't even consider some viable options b/c of flawed ethos of growth beyond everything else. what's really amazing is we have so much good data on this company and its markets yet the no see/hear/speak monkey is in full display.

Message.Msg: very on the mark post - however I really think Bernanke is not protecting the banking cartel as much as he actually thinks the wealth effect of higher prices will lift us out of the mud and mire and put us on a firm stand. he really believes this in his heart of hearts. i'm a little surprised he doesn't get that there is no free lunch and the cost is lower currency value, higher costs and the most damaging - continuation of increasing debt load.

Topic.Title: AMZN stock seems very sensitive to upside bids today: the momo gamblers are in the sandbox the last two days after it was hit down to 255-6

Message.Msg: Should have been specific. Fed will fail to stimulate/improve economy with printing... Real economy is in recession, but no one will be able to hide it by 2013. Only the structural deficit is enabling nominal GDP growth now. IMF study concluded that Europe had more contraction in GDP than had been anticipated because multiplers on gov't spending are higher in this environment. Fed itself will not fail. FWIW, I've said the MBS purchases are good strategy -- the Fed is getting claims on additional physical assets printed money which will help maintain the currency if the gold bugs are right and it doesn't have all the gold it should...
Sell your 265 puts and calls tomorrow morning.

Topic.Title: AMZN stock seems very sensitive to upside bids today: the momo gamblers are in the sandbox the last two days after it was hit down to 255-6

Message.Msg: I think he did believe in the wealth effect. But, he's now realizing that when 10% of the people control 80% of financial assets, the wealth effect CANNOT sustain a consumption oriented economy. And the problem is mutlidimensional because we have the same structural issues on the business side as we have on the household side.

Message.Msg: that's exactly what he's doing:except the 'wealth effect" he gets is mostly for Bezos types in stocks like AMZN, that don't have any proven earnings record. That's a gross misallocation of capital via paper engineering: and puts the flow of money into a hands of fews at the expense of most. And it's proven to NOT be sustainable longterm. If they had not created these asset bubble via over debt issuance, this Country would not have a deflation problem to begin with. It's all their "estimating" with BS models that are a big part of it. Your supposed to let markets clear the system, the Fed's policies get in the way of that: and keep funnelling money in the direction of their "overseers" creating very shaky unpinning, foundations to the system here. Now bond yields have to stay below 2 % to keep the debt behomoth from imploding.

Topic.Title: Tech - on today market move so far

Message.Msg: The 13G's show that many solid funds have rotated out of Amazon during this run ... but there have been other funds that absorbed all of the stock and then some .. like Capital world investors, that now own over $7.4B worth of AMZN, an incredible amount of money to be one stock. They added 28M shares last year and alone could have driven the stock to where it is. We do not know if they have added this year or not. When they exit it could be ugly.

Message.Title: Opex scamers had to wait for Lunch to avoid volume and drive price back to 265
Message.Msg: Like clock work, money was exiting in good volume prior to lunch, and then drop erased while no one was looking. It took less half of the volume to move the stock back up the $3 is lost.

Topic.Title: Tech - on today market move so far

Message.Msg: Capital World bought because no one else was at that time IMHO. It sold tons of AAPL and is likely behind the AAPL killing that transpired over the past 6 months so that in the market cap weighted index rebalancing everyone would end up selling AAPL and buying more overvalued Amazon. It seems that Cap World is now all in. It better hope no one decides to act like an investor rebalance between Amazon and Apple to reflect fundamentals (which would put the relative weighting at about 10 $ AAPL to $1 AMZN). Someday when all the stress in the system in gone and Amazon craters, CapWorld will have extraordinary explaining to do IMHO.

Message.Msg: It always closes a little above to unload onto call buyers... All part of the system of unloading via the upper deck... You'll know it really is breaking when one of the institutional longs that CapWorld screwed through the AAPL kill decides to hold it below the max pain call exercise price so the quant cannot unload via calls all the shares it took on to prop the price while killing puts. That's when the game is over...

Topic.Title: Funny thought: At this rate, AAPL can take itself private and pay off the loan in 5 years with FCF

Message.Msg: Once, any institutional long not selling AMZN and buying AAPL here is just negligent unless they've already maxed out AAPL weighting. The ratio of APPL/AMZN EV is about a factor of 2, where in a year it will be more like a factor of 10 again... I've never seen such a clear way to reduce risk and increase upside simultaneously... AAPL has $150B in cash and can weather whatever comes. AMZN is almost out of net cash (sorry folks, payables are obligations to suppliers) and just raised debt...

Topic.Title: Funny thought: At this rate, AAPL can take itself private and pay off the loan in 5 years with FCF

Message.Msg: Kenji: AAPL is trading at an EV/EBITDA of just over 6. It doesn't need to sell at a record pace... If it could simply hold profits close to these levels, that is a pretty extraordinary cash flow yield in this environment. While AAPL has earnings risk (as everyone does), it has the cash to weather any storm and, actually, can deploy that cash for strategic acquisitions once the bubble bursts. It would survive for years with no revenue (most of the mfg cost lie elsewhere with partners...). Plus, its global earnings make it a real currency hedge as well... Amazon OTOH.... Apple can and should sit on its cash and let WS beat it down. When things are at their darkest, then it should deploy the cash to buybacks and acquisitions...

Topic.Title: Funny thought: At this rate, AAPL can take itself private and pay off the loan in 5 years with FCF

Message.Msg: AAPL needs to do something .. If I were on the BOD, I would double the dividend, and then buy back $80B worth of stock (~ 20% of the company, or 185M shares). Removing 20% of the shares, with a 2x increase of dividend, results in only a 60% increase in payout, even though you increase the yield by 100%. The stock will get back to $550 in a hearbeat with increased demand and lack of supply. The amazing thing is that they would still have $57B in cash, and only about 40% of FCF tied up in the increased dividend.
